title: How to Manually Auto Tune With Audacity

steps.title: Download the GSnap plugin.
steps.content: Download the GSnap plugin. Go to https://www.gvst.co.uk/gsnap.htm in a web browser, then click the Download GSnap (for 32-bit VST hosts) link near the bottom of the page. The GSnap plugin will download in a ZIP folder. The 64-bit version has a bug which prevents GSnap from showing up in the Effects menu.

steps.title: Extract the GSnap folder.
steps.content: Extract the GSnap folder. Go to the downloaded ZIP folder, then do the following: Double-click the ZIP folder to open it. Click the Extract tab at the top of the window. Click Extract all Click Extract at the bottom of the window.

steps.title: Copy the GSnap folder contents.
steps.content: Copy the GSnap folder contents. In the extracted folder that opens, press Ctrl + A to select the folder's files, then press Ctrl + C to copy everything.

steps.title: Click This PC.
steps.content: Click This PC . It's a folder on the left side of the File Explorer window. This will open the This PC folder. You may have to scroll up in the left-hand sidebar of File Explorer to find this folder.

steps.title: Double-click your computer's hard drive.
steps.content: Double-click your computer's hard drive. This option is below the "Devices and drives" heading in the middle of the page, and is usually the OS (C:) option. If you don't see any drives listed here, first click the Devices and drives heading to make them appear.

steps.title: Navigate to the Audacity "Plug-Ins" folder.
steps.content: Navigate to the Audacity "Plug-Ins" folder. To do so: Double-click the "Program Files (x86)" folder. Double-click the "Audacity" folder. Double-click the "Plug-Ins" folder.

steps.title: Paste in the GSnap files.
steps.content: Paste in the GSnap files. Click anywhere in the "Plug-Ins" folder, then press Ctrl + V . You should see both of the GSnap files that you copied appear in the "Plug-Ins" folder. Now that you've added the GSnap plug-in to Audacity, you'll need to enable GSnap . If prompted, you'll need to click Continue before the files will paste into Audacity.

steps.title: Download the GVST plug-ins package.
steps.content: Download the GVST plug-ins package. Go to https://www.gvst.co.uk/portpage.htm in your web browser, then click the Download GVST plug-ins for Mac (for 32- and 64-bit VST hosts) link below the "Mac OSX - BETA" heading. GSnap isn't available as an individual download for Mac computers, which is why you're downloading all VST plug-ins here.

steps.title: Open the downloaded ZIP folder.
steps.content: Open the downloaded ZIP folder. Double-click the GVST plug-ins ZIP folder that you downloaded to do so.

steps.title: Copy the GSnap file.
steps.content: Copy the GSnap file. Click the file entitled "GSnap", then press ⌘ Command + C . You can also click File and then click the Copy option in the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click the Go menu item.
steps.content: Click the Go menu item. You'll find it at the top of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear. If you don't see Go at the top of your Mac's screen, click the desktop or open a new Finder window.

steps.title: Click Go to Folder….
steps.content: Click Go to Folder… . It's near the bottom of the Go drop-down menu. Doing so opens a pop-up window. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Go to the Audacity Application Support folder.
steps.content: Go to the Audacity Application Support folder. Type ~/Library/Application Support/audacity into the text box in the pop-up window, then click Go .

steps.title: Open the "Plug-Ins" folder.
steps.content: Open the "Plug-Ins" folder. You should find this option in the "audacity" folder.

steps.title: Paste in the GSnap file.
steps.content: Paste in the GSnap file. Click inside of the "Plug-Ins" folder, then press ⌘ Command + V . Doing so will place the GSnap file inside of the "Plug-Ins" folder, thus adding it to Audacity. Now that you've added the GSnap plug-in to Audacity, you'll need to enable GSnap . You can also click File and then click Paste Item in the resulting drop-down menu.

steps.title: Open Audacity.
steps.content: Open Audacity. Its app icon resembles an orange soundwave surrounded by blue headphones. Audacity's track editor view will open in a new window.

steps.title: Click Effect.
steps.content: Click Effect . This tab is at the top of the Audacity window. Clicking it prompts a drop-down menu. On a Mac, Effect is a menu item at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Click "Add / Remove Plug-ins…".
steps.content: Click "Add / Remove Plug-ins…". You'll find this option at the top of the Effect drop-down menu. Clicking it opens a new window. You may have to scroll up to find this option.

steps.title: Scroll down and click "GSnap".
steps.content: Scroll down and click "GSnap". It's in the "G" section of the window.

steps.title: Click Enable.
steps.content: Click Enable . This button is below the list of available plug-ins. Doing so will switch GSnap's status from "New" to "Enabled".

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . It's at the bottom of the window. Clicking it will confirm your changes and close the window.

steps.title: Make sure that GSnap was installed.
steps.content: Make sure that GSnap was installed. Click the Effect tab, then scroll down until you see GSnap near the bottom of the menu. If you see GSnap , you're all set to proceed with auto-tuning your vocals in Audacity. If you don't see GSnap here, you most likely installed the 64-bit version of GSnap on a Windows computer. You'll have to delete the GSnap file from the Audacity "Plug-Ins" folder and re-download the 32-bit version of GSnap.

steps.title: Import your vocals.
steps.content: Import your vocals. Click File , select Import , click Audio... , and double-click the audio file that you want to auto-tune. If you haven't yet recorded your vocals, you'll need to record them before proceeding. This may include attaching a USB microphone to your computer.

steps.title: Select your vocals.
steps.content: Select your vocals. Click and drag your mouse across the section of the vocals that you want to auto-tune. You can select everything in Audacity by pressing Ctrl + A .

steps.title: Click Effect.
steps.content: Click Effect . The drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click "GSnap…".
steps.content: Click "GSnap…". It's near the bottom of the Effect drop-down menu. The GSnap window will open. You may have to scroll down at the bottom of the drop-down menu in order to find the GSnap... option.

steps.title: Select a key.
steps.content: Select a key. Click the SELECT A SCALE... button at the top of the window, select your song's key (e.g., A ), select Major or Minor , and click OK

steps.title: Set the knobs to auto-tune levels.
steps.content: Set the knobs to auto-tune levels. Though you can play with these knobs as much as you want to get a unique sound, use the following settings to get the "classic" autotune sound: MIN FREQ : 80 hz MAX FREQ : 2000 hz GATE : -40 db SPEED : Between 1 (choppy vocals) and 10 (smoother vocals) THRESHOLD : 100 cents AMOUNT : 100% ATTACK : 1 ms RELEASE : 61 ms

steps.title: Preview your settings.
steps.content: Preview your settings. Click the green "Play" button in the lower-left side of the window, then listen to the vocals.

steps.title: Make any necessary adjustments.
steps.content: Make any necessary adjustments. The two main things to monitor are the "AMOUNT" value and the "SPEED" value: AMOUNT - 100 percent results in the largest amount of auto-tuning, so lower this value if there's too much autotune. SPEED - A low speed results in choppier, T-Pain-esque vocals, whereas a higher number will result in smoother vocals. You can also remove the sharps and flats by clicking the green circles on the black keys that are on the left side of the window.

steps.title: Click Apply.
steps.content: Click Apply . It's in the bottom-right corner of the window. Doing so will apply the selected settings to your track.

steps.title: Customize your auto-tune.
steps.content: Customize your auto-tune. Keep playing with the settings to find the sound you want, but keep in mind the following: Larger "ATTACK" and "RELEASE" times make your voice sound more natural. Adding vibrato can make you sound more natural. The lower the "THRESHOLD" value, the more robotic you'll sound. The farther off-key you are on the recording, the more "auto-tuned" your voice will sound when you're done.

steps.title: Save your project as a music file.
steps.content: Save your project as a music file. You can export the track as its own song by clicking File , clicking Export Audio... , entering a name and save location, and clicking Save . If prompted to add tags (e.g., the artist name), you can add them or skip the process entirely.
